title: The Neuroscience of Drumming: Researchers Discover the Secrets of Drumming
excerpt: An old musician’s joke goes “there are three kinds of drummers in the world—those who can count and those who can’t.” But perhaps there is an even more global divide. Perhaps there are three kinds of people in the world—those who can drum and those who can’t.

title: Why Do We Even Listen to New Music?
excerpt: Our brains reward us for seeking out what we already know. So why should we reach to listen to something we don’t?

title: Is Music Universal?
excerpt: From a neurological and evolutionary perspective, music is fascinating. There seems to be a deeply rooted biological appreciation for tonality, rhythm, and melody. title: Why We Remember Music and Forget Everything Else
excerpt: Psychologists say it's no surprise that we have such a strong memory for music and can easily recall lyrics and melodies, even if we haven’t heard them in years.

title: Neuroscience: Music, silence, and prediction
excerpt: For the first time, the authors of a recent study isolated the electrical neural signals of prediction by studying moments of silence in music.

title: Brain Damage Saved His Music - Issue 20: Creativity - Nautilus

title: How Bionic Gloves Gave a Maestro Pianist His Hands Back
